item.title: Alyssa Healy's path to Australian cricket greatness was far from straightforward
item.description: Alyssa Healy was thrust into headlines when she was just 16 for daring to break into a literal old boys' club, but has expertly handled the national spotlight with bat, ball and microphone in hand.

item.title: Regional NSW boy accused of hoax emergency calls about mass shootings at US institutions
item.description: A "young boy" from regional New South Wales is accused of making fake emergency calls claiming mass shootings were taking place at major retail and education institutions in the United States.

item.title: Former A-League player Josh Cavallo alleges Adelaide United was homophobic
item.description: Australia's first openly gay male professional footballer, Josh Cavallo, has alleged his former club was homophobic, something it denies.

item.title: Record number of black and grey-headed flying foxes die during east coast heatwave
item.description: Wildlife rescuers warn extreme heat could kill more black and grey-headed flying foxes across NSW, with 700 dead animals already removed from two Illawarra camps.

item.title: Minnesota and the Twin Cities sue US federal government to stop immigration crackdown
item.description: Minnesota and its two cities sue the Trump administration in a bid to stop an immigration crackdown that led to the fatal shooting of Renee Good last week.

item.title: SA premier becomes emotional in press conference
item.description: Peter Malinauskas becomes tearful during a media conference where he faces extensive questions about the crisis surrounding Adelaide Writers' Week and allegations of homophobia against Adelaide United made by former player Josh Cavallo.

item.title: Rudd leaves US-Australia relationship in good shape ahead of Trump's China visit
item.description: One month after Kevin Rudd leaves his post as Australia's ambassador to Washington, Donald Trump will make his first presidential visit to China in almost 10 years.

item.title: Fears of unseen violence against protesters as Iran's internet blackout enters a fifth day
item.description: Human rights groups estimate more than 500 people have been killed and more than 10,600 arrested in the ongoing protests.

item.title: Mount Alexander fire knocks out TV and radio across central Victoria
item.description: A fast-moving fire has silenced free-to-air TV and radio across central Victoria — and it could take months to fix the site.

item.title: Tasmanian pianist takes outdoor performances to striking mainland locations
item.description: Kelvin Smith played a baby grand piano at some incredible sites across Tasmania before bringing his impromptu shows to amazing mainland locations.

item.title: Suzi Milgate receives suspended sentence for crepe attack on former NT chief minister
item.description: The woman who assaulted a former Northern Territory chief minister with a cream crepe is sentenced to 12 months imprisonment, fully suspended.

item.title: Bridge fire near tourist town of Byron Bay highlights region's homelessness crisis
item.description: A bridge used daily by thousands of drivers is shut in northern NSW, after a fire beneath it destroys the camps of two homeless men with "nowhere else to go".

item.title: Adelaide Writers' Week cancelled amid controversy over disinvitation of author Randa Abdel-Fattah
item.description: The remaining members of the Adelaide Festival board will step down and this year's Writers' Week event has been cancelled, after days of furore regarding the decision to cancel a scheduled appearance by Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah.

item.title: Police say no ongoing threat to public safety, 18yo man in custody after Pinjarra firearms incident
item.description: Police say they have located an 18-year-old man wanted in connection with a firearms incident in Pinjarra on Tuesday morning.

item.title: l decluttered my wardrobe and said goodbye to 'fantasy me'
item.description: I was tired of trying to live up to an idealised version of myself. So, I decided to do something I had learnt from Marie Kondo: sort my wardrobe into what brought me joy and what didn't.

item.title: Koala captured on motion-sensor camera in rare sighting near Canberra
item.description: A motion-sensor camera has captured the rare sight of a koala in the wild at a wildlife sanctuary in Googong near the ACT border.

item.title: Carnarvon growers enjoy massive mango season, bringing prices down for consumers
item.description: A WA mango grower is pleasantly surprised to find a crop full of massive mangoes, as big as a bowling ball.

item.title: Jasper Jones author Craig Silvey faces Fremantle court over alleged child exploitation offences
item.description: One of Australia's most renowned authors, Craig Silvey, faces court after he allegedly distributed child exploitation material.

item.title: Venus Williams exits Hobart International after straight-sets loss to Tatjana Maria
item.description: After being awarded a wildcard at the age of 45, seven-time major singles champion Venus Williams falls in the opening round in Hobart.

item.title: Ruffy community determined to rebuild after Longwood bushfire destroys Victorian town
item.description: Residents in the central Victorian community of Ruffy say they are determined to rebuild after a bushfire destroyed most buildings in the small community.

item.title: Sydney Festival show asses.masses combines participatory theatre and the social fabric of playing video games together
item.description: Theatre makers Patrick Blenkarn and Milton Lim have built a game to be played socially in an auditorium, with a single player leading a group of donkeys on a journey of discovery.

item.title: Chad Littmann pleads guilty to lighting two small fires in Royal National Park
item.description: A magistrate tells a 48-year-old bus driver prison is his "only possible sentence" after he lit two small fires near Sydney in December.

item.title: Tuesday finance with Alan Kohler
item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: More than 500 structures lost as Victoria continues to reel from devastating bushfires
item.description: Communities around Victoria continue to count the cost of devastating bushfires, with more than 500 structures — including 179 homes — lost or damaged so far.

item.title: Chaos in Melbourne court as Brendan Nicholls is denied bail over alleged imam assault
item.description: A Melbourne courtroom descended into chaos as the 23-year-old man accused of assaulting Ismet Purdic and his wife attempted to climb out of the dock moments after being denied bail.

item.title: Public transport bypassed in Labor's Mount Barker re-election promises
item.description: Labor today announced a $200 million investment in Mount Barker as part of its bid to win the seat of Kavel, but while some of those initiatives have been welcomed, there was a glaring omission in public transport solutions.

item.title: Liberals divided over Labor's plan to outlaw inciting racial hatred
item.description: After weeks criticising the Albanese government over the Bondi attack and issues around antisemitism, the Coalition is split over whether proposed solutions are at odds with its interests in preserving freedom of speech.

item.title: Former Adelaide Writers' Week director Louise Adler attacks government and lobby groups over censorship
item.description: The former Adelaide Writers' Week director takes aim at lobby groups and the SA premier during an intense appearance on 7.30 in which she says the event's reputation has been "trashed".

item.title: Car thieves going high-tech
item.description: Sarah Ferguson presents Australia's premier daily current affairs program, delivering agenda-setting public affairs journalism and interviews that hold the powerful to account. Plus political analysis from Laura Tingle.

item.title: The cricket bat maker taking his trade to the world
item.description: Sarah Ferguson presents Australia's premier daily current affairs program, delivering agenda-setting public affairs journalism and interviews that hold the powerful to account. Plus political analysis from Laura Tingle.

item.title: Police conduct large-scale search in Darwin's East Point Reserve for man missing for 10 days
item.description: Police have conducted a large-scale search-and-rescue operation in Darwin's East Point Reserve on Tuesday, after phone triangulation revealed it to be the last known location of a man missing for 10 days.

item.title: Global financial markets to face major test next week as central bankers support Powell
item.description: Lisa Cook vs the US government will hit the courts next week. The case comes as Australia's Reserve Bank governor, Michele Bullock, signs a letter in support of US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell, who is facing a criminal investigation in the United States.

item.title: Around 2,500 reportedly killed in protests as Donald Trump tells Iranians 'help is on its way'
item.description: Activists say around 2,500 people have been killed in protests against the country's ruling Islamic regime.

item.title: Clintons refuse to testify for US House Epstein investigation
item.description: Republicans in the US House say they could commence contempt of Congress proceedings against the former president and former Democratic presidential nominee.

item.title: Prosecutors seek death penalty for Yoon Suk Yeol in South Korea after martial law call
item.description: Yoon Suk Yeol faces several criminal charges related to his call to impose martial law and other criminal cases related to his time in office.

item.title: Eloise Worledge investigation overlooked a known rapist in Beaumaris
item.description: As police up the reward to $1 million for information that will lead to the remains of missing school girl Eloise Worledge, questions remain about why police disregarded a known rapist in their investigation.

item.title: Victoria's bushfires more than five times the size of Singapore
item.description: Victoria's bushfires have now burnt across 404,000 hectares, or a total area more than five times the size of Singapore.

item.title: Documents reveal tensions over Kunanyi/Mt Wellington access plans debate
item.description: Loved by bushwalkers and tourists, a sacred Aboriginal site, and with weather conditions that can quickly deteriorate, Hobart's Kunanyi/Mount Wellington is a challenge to manage — and a government review of how that is done is being met with concerns.

item.title: Rare verified footage of Iran's protests posted online shows how the movement started and how it is growing
item.description: The first embers of the Iranian protests started in a mobile phone market, spreading to every corner of the country as the Revolutionary Guard struggled to regain control.

item.title: Natimuk praised for 'heroic' response to fast-moving fire that claimed 30 homes
item.description: The Natimuk community counts its losses after fire tears through the region, destroying properties, businesses and about 30 homes.

item.title: Racism targeting migrant truck drivers rampant amid regulatory gaps
item.description: Some Indian truck drivers have copped so much racist abuse they have stopped using their CB radios.

item.title: Future of Bondi Beach terror attack site up for debate as replacement flagged
item.description: The Bondi Beach footbridge that some locals want removed following last month's terror attack was already going to need replacement for structural reasons.

item.title: A tearful premier and 'Moscow on the Torrens': How to lose a writers' week in six days
item.description: The removal and subsequent handling of Randa Abdel-Fattah's rescinded invitation to Adelaide Writers' Week led to the event's cancellation, with more than 180 authors pulling out and its own director issuing a pointed and very public resignation. Where does the festival go from here?

item.title: When does the Australian Open 2026 start and who are the favourites to win?
item.description: With the 2026 Australian Open just around the corner here's everything you need to know about the tournament.

item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Goat's headbutt frenzy causes thousands of dollars in damage to Cobar business
item.description: After finding his shopfront smashed, Shane Martin checked his CCTV to find that a feral goat was the culprit.

item.title: Neurosurgeon Richard Laherty among five charged in Queensland crime and corruption investigation
item.description: The ABC can reveal a neurosurgeon specialising in spinal surgery is among five people facing serious charges over a Queensland scheme allegedly involving kickbacks for medical devices.

item.title: Kingaroy Vinnies volunteer adopts chihuahua dumped in donation crate
item.description: The chihuahua-cross was rescued by Vinnies volunteers who named the puppy "Vinnie". The charity says it is rare but unfortunately not unheard of for live animals to be donated.

item.title: Feral goat costs Cobar business thousands
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Simple ways to reduce your exposure to microplastics around the home
item.description: Researchers say there are some simple ways to help minimise our exposure to the microplastics and nanoplastics in our homes.

item.title: Overcrowding concerns raised after suspicious fire at popular beach near Esperance
item.description: Hundreds of people were evacuated from an area near Wharton Beach on Western Australia's south coast in the early hours of New Year's Day after a blaze broke out.

item.title: Proposed changes to Queensland local government law a 'retrograde step', association warns
item.description: The legislation, introduced by the government late last year, would automatically remove a mayor or councillor from office if they run for state parliament.

item.title: Randa Abdel-Fattah says lawyers have threatened defamation proceedings against Peter Malinauskas
item.description: Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah says her lawyers have threatened defamation proceedings against South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas following his public commentary about her scheduled appearance at Adelaide Writers' Week.

item.title: Police charge 18yo man with being armed in a way that may cause fear in Pinjarra
item.description: An 18-year-old man faces court charged with being armed in a way that may cause fear over an incident that sparked a major response from police in Pinjarra, south of Perth.

item.title: Tom Silvagni files application to appeal rape conviction
item.description: Lawyers for convicted rapist Tom Silvagni, the son of AFL great Stephen Silvagni and TV personality Jo Silvagni, have filed an application for leave to appeal.

item.title: Carranballac Cricket Club reduced to ashes after fire in western Victorian community of Streatham
item.description: Leigh Graham lost his home and his "second home" — his local cricket club's rooms — in the fires that moved through the western Victorian community of Streatham. He still turned up to play two days later.

item.title: K-pop supergroup BTS announce Australian tour dates after military service
item.description: The K-pop supergroup announce their first Australian tour dates since being discharged from the South Korean military.

item.title: Thanasi Kokkinakis withdraws from Adelaide International after injury setback
item.description: Adelaide native Thanasi Kokkinakis withdraws from his home tournament on the eve of the Australian Open after suffering another injury setback in his opening-round win.

item.title: Former NRLW Blues captain Maddison Studdon facing domestic violence charge
item.description: Maddison Studdon is accused of harassing her ex-partner as their relationship broke down, culminating in 29 calls and an alleged "throat-slitting" gesture over cheating claims.

item.title: There is now a strong likelihood Donald Trump will order his military option of choice on Iran
item.description: The Iranian regime has done exactly what Donald Trump warned against. Despite the information blackout, it is clear hundreds, if not thousands, of protesters have died and the US president is now likely to order a response, writes John Lyons.

item.title: Velvet Pesu, carer found dead at Logan house, remembered as 'larger than life' as man faces court
item.description: Velvet Pesu was found dead during a police welfare check at a house in the Logan suburb of Buccan.

item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.description: Researchers are asking for the public's help to learn more about the health of the albino whale, which was seen from Crescent Head on the Mid North Coast.

item.title: Australian Open qualifying: Bernard Tomic easily beaten by Arthur Fery, Olivia Gadecki knocked out
item.description: Bernard Tomic was brushed past by Britain's Arthur Fery in their second round match, while Olivia Gadecki was beaten by Sloane Stephens.

item.title: Publishers, bookstores pull Craig Silvey's work in response to child exploitation material charges
item.description: The fallout of the high-profile child exploitation material allegations against Craig Silvey starts to ripple through the literary community, as the renowned author faces charges of possessing and distributing illicit material.

item.title: Our changing climate in 2025 in pictures and graphs as Australia kicks off year with extreme heat, fires
item.description: Extreme heat, droughts, storms and deadly floods challenged resilience not only in Australia, but across the globe.

item.title: SA man pleads guilty to manslaughter of wife, not guilty to murder
item.description: A South Australian man is due to stand trial after admitting to the manslaughter of his wife at a northern suburbs home, but has told a court he is not guilty of her murder.

item.title: These were the most-borrowed books from Brisbane libraries in 2025
item.description: New data has revealed there were 5.9 million physical items — including books, CDs and DVDs — checked out of Brisbane libraries in 2025.

item.title: Investigation launched into man's death at Wide Bay hospital
item.description: An investigation has been launched into the sudden death of a man in the Fraser Coast.

item.title: Socceroos midfielder Jackson Irvine ruled out 'until further notice' with recurrence of foot injury
item.description: Socceroos midfielder Jackson Irvine is facing an extended stint on the sidelines heading into this year's World Cup.

item.title: Pilbara home to five animal species most impacted by habitat loss, report finds
item.description: The Australian Conservation Foundation says tens of thousands of hectares of land were approved for clearing last year, double that of 2024, putting already endangered species at further risk.

item.title: Farmers hurt by Victorian fires to receive $50m state and federal support package
item.description: The Allan government says it will provide grants and loans to support farmers who have lost homes, livestock, infrastructure and feed in the Victorian fires.

item.title: Man hoarding footballs convicted of dangerous driving and fined after years-long 'pranking' by kids
item.description: A Tasmanian man who had "had enough" after becoming the target of "pranks" by kids, had hoarded "hundreds" of footballs kicked into his yard from the neighbouring school, a court hears.

item.title: Prayer hall linked to notorious preacher Wisam Haddad to close permanently
item.description: A controversial prayer hall in south-west Sydney linked to notorious Islamic preacher Wisam Haddad has announced it will permanently close.

item.title: China reports $US1.2 trillion trade surplus in 2025 despite Trump trade war
item.description: A shift away from the United States toward South-East Asia, Africa and Latin America has helped Chinese exports remain strong.

item.title: At least 32 killed after crane falls on passenger train in Thailand
item.description: A crane used to construct an elevated high-speed railway has fallen onto a moving train travelling from Bangkok to Ubon Ratchathani province, officials say.

item.description: About 150 jobs will be created by a new "green cement" project at a power station site which has sat vacant for nearly a decade, the SA government says.

item.description: Representatives of the Jewish community and Australian National Imams Council front a snap parliamentary hearing called to probe Labor's legislative response to the Bondi terror attack.

item.title: 'Significant' theft of toxic poppies could cause death, Tasmanian authorities warn
item.description: The theft of a "significant quantity" of medicinal-grade poppies could result in a "life-threatening" situation if they are ingested in pursuit of a high, Tasmanian authorities warn.

item.title: Taylah Preston makes Hobart International quarterfinals after upset win over Rebecca Sramkova
item.description: The 20-year-old world number 204, who also has a wildcard at the upcoming Australian Open, won the match against the world number 72 6-4, 6-1.

item.title: Alyssa Healy taken aback by reaction to commentary stints as post-retirement career seems assured
item.description: After calling time on her decorated 15-year career, a spell in media commentary looks inevitable for Australian cricket star Alyssa Healy.

item.description: The head of Adelaide United says the former Reds player Josh Cavallo never raised concerns about homophobia or not being selected to play based on his sexuality while at the A-League club.

item.description: Amid the damage from flooding in central Queensland, tales of livestock surviving are emerging, including one cow's incredible waterlogged journey.

item.description: Velvet Pesu was found dead at a house in Logan on Monday while police were conducting a welfare check.

item.description: Builders working in the rear yard of a surveying company got a shock when they came across a hessian sack full of old mining explosives.

item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.description: The men will serve four months in prison after being caught off the WA coast with 40 kilograms of sea cucumber and an array of fishing gear.

item.description: Geraldton windsurfer Sarah Kenyon is victorious after a tight battle in the sport's junior world championships held in regional WA for the first time.

item.description: As the Adelaide Festival director reveals he had urged the festival's board not to cancel Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah, a former board member opens up about his very different concerns about the Adelaide Writers' Week program.

item.title: Tasmanian commercial fishers warned about potential antibiotic contamination from salmon pens
item.description: Tasmania's Natural Resources and Environment Department has warned commercial fishers that driving their boats near some salmon pens could result in their onboard catch absorbing traces of the antibiotic florfenicol.

item.description: No Limit boss George Rose says the doorway to the world will open for the winner of the Nikita Tszyu and Michael Zerafa grudge boxing showdown.

item.description: Police charge 25 youths and seize and destroy dozens of electric scooters and off-road bikes in a targeted crackdown on e-rideables in Perth's northern suburbs.

item.description: Police are urging Canberrans not to touch suspicious objects after pipe bombs were discovered in Belconnen.

item.description: Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke says he believes tobacco kingpin Kaz Hamad thought he was "out of reach" of authorities before his arrest in Iraq.

item.title: Iran warns of retaliation as US withdraws troops from Middle East bases
item.description: It comes as Iran's judiciary defies US warnings and says those detained over anti-regime protests could face execution, although the Iranian foreign ‌minister says there is no plan to hang people.

item.description: Sydneysider Jordan Smith has beaten grand slam champion Jannik Sinner and dual grand slam finalist Amanda Anasimova to take home the prize in the novelty format.

item.title: X to change AI chatbot after outrage over sexual deepfake images
item.description: New laws in the UK that would outlaw the generation of sexual deepfakes are set to come into force this week.

item.title: FBI raids home and seizes devices of Washington Post journalist
item.description: The reporter had previously reported on the Trump administration's efforts to fire hundreds of thousands of federal workers.

item.title: What it's like working at Casey Station in Antarctica
item.description: From 6,000 applications each year, only about 300 make the cut to travel down to Antarctica and experience a workplace like no other.

item.title: Today in history, January 15: Australia's London Bridge fell down
item.description: Seconds after her cousin reassured her crossing it was safe, the famous Great Ocean Road formation started collapsing beneath Kelli Bryers's feet, setting off a terrifying ordeal.

item.title: Can you guess how overdue and over budget these Grand Designs Transformations renovations were?
item.description: It's a familiar story on design shows. Home owners launch into building projects with budgets and timelines that don't always match their lofty ambitions. Take our quiz to measure your renovation planning skills.

item.title: Tens of thousands of livestock confirmed dead as Victorians return to bushfire-ravaged communities
item.description: Around 260 homes have been confirmed destroyed and 20,000 head of livestock killed by bushfires across Victoria, with authorities warning the total is likely to rise.

item.title: Sussan Ley signals Liberals won’t back 'unsalvageable' hate crime and gun control reforms
item.description: Liberals are backing away from a push to tackle antisemitism with stronger racial hatred laws, with some senior figures in the party also voicing freedom of speech concerns.

item.title: Who to see at Tamworth Country Music Festival 2026 — top artists and event details
item.description: Discover the must-see artists at the 2026 Tamworth Country Music Festival — from breakout stars like Lane Pittman to legends such as Felicity Urquhart. Your ultimate guide to shows, dates, and insider tips.

item.title: From inside Iran, a young protester says the people 'are waiting for America to intervene'
item.description: A defiant voice bravely breaks through Iran's internet blackout to detail the horrors she has witnessed and to tell the president of the United States "the people are waiting for America to intervene".

item.title: Severe thunderstorms and flooding to hit eastern seaboard in weather switch-up
item.description: Severe thunderstorms and flooding rain are expected to ease the short-term fire threat, while Queensland continues to be drenched from ex-Tropical Cyclone Koji.

item.title: Rental market growth stalls in some capital cities as household budgets stretched to limit
item.description: Australia's rental market is "starting to rebalance" with prices flat in some capital cities but affordability remains a concern, according to Domain, which says an annual salary of $100,000 is needed to live comfortably.

item.title: Writers' Week cancellation highlights SA premier's uneasy relationship with the arts
item.description: After backing the Adelaide Festival's decision to drop a Palestinian Australian author from Writers' Week, Peter Malinauskas is now trying to distance himself from a crisis that threatens to do untold damage to South Australia's festival reputation.

item.title: Jafar Panahi is ready to go to prison for the film the Iranian government doesn't want you to see
item.description: Would you face prison for what you believe in? Iranian filmmaker Jafar Panahi already has and, following the release of his latest film, he may again.

item.title: Reopening Gulgong Medical Centre a 'lifeline' for the community
item.description: Gulgong went 18 months without a GP clinic. It has now reopened, giving residents a reprieve from travelling hundreds of kilometres to see a doctor.

item.title: Controversial group Hizb ut-Tahrir says it 'cannot be banned' despite proposed laws targeting hate speech
item.description: Controversial group Hizb ut-Tahrir says the government "cannot ban" its ideas, despite its members facing the threat of jail under proposed hate speech laws to go before parliament.

item.title: Trauma medics warn over-60s against climbing ladders as 6,000 people hospitalised in a year
item.description: Thousands of people present to Australian hospitals each year for ladder and roof falls, with doctors urging caution — particularly for ageing Australians.

item.title: Trump to write next chapter of US relations with Iran after decades of tensions
item.description: From a CIA-led coup to a hostage crisis and air strikes, here are some of the defining moments in seven decades of relations between the United States and Iran.

item.title: Tree bark microbes play a role in eliminating greenhouse gases, study finds
item.description: Tiny, gas-eating microbes hidden in the bark of trees offer scientists a crucial clue in the fight against global warming.

item.title: Denmark, US fail to agree over Greenland after high-level talks at White House
item.description: The United States and Denmark continue to disagree over the future of Greenland after a meeting at the White House amid ongoing threats from President Donald Trump threatening to seize the semi-autonomous Danish territory for national security reasons.

item.title: Residents near Mackenzie River on high alert as flood warning continues
item.description: Communities in Queensland's central highlands region remain on high alert today as major flooding continues along the Mackenzie River.

item.title: NT set to fall short of Indigenous law and justice target despite early success
item.description: Despite the NT government signing on to establish 20 Aboriginal Law and Justice Groups by 2027, just five are up and running with less than 12 months to go.

item.title: Daniel Sanders suffers broken collarbone in Dakar Rally crash, losing lead but vows to ride on
item.description: Daniel Sanders says he has broken his collarbone and sternum in a crash on stage 10 of the Dakar Rally, but vows to finish the last three stages.

item.title: Live updates: Microsoft signs AI deal with ACTU, ASX to rise after Wall Street slides
item.description: Australia's peak union body moves to shore up tech, creative and media jobs, while the ASX is flat after another Wall Street slide. Follow the day's events and insights as they happen with our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

item.title: US to suspend immigrant visa processing for 75 countries, including Fiji
item.description: The US State Department will suspend processing of immigrant visas for people from 75 countries, including Fiji, Cambodia, Thailand, Somalia and Brazil, from January 21.

item.title: Volunteer firefighters, councils paying for Starlink connections as poor mobile reception continues across WA
item.description: Having repeatedly lost mobile coverage during recent bushfires, local councils and volunteer brigades are paying for expensive satellite units to maintain critical communications.

item.title: As Adelaide Writers' Week is cancelled, what is the future of writers' festivals in Australia?
item.description: The shock cancellation of Adelaide Writers' Week has left many concerned about the future of writers' festivals in an increasingly polarised political world.

item.title: Regulator investigates alleged breach of Alcoa's mining exemption conditions
item.description: WA's environmental regulator is investigating an alleged breach of Alcoa's state-imposed mining conditions which, if proven, would make it illegal for the company to continue some of its mining operations.

item.title: Australia's vet access deserts where an hour's drive is the difference in life and death
item.description: More than 250,000 people do not have ready access to a vet in Australia, and according to the industry it is not completely down to a shortage. It is also a distribution issue which is also putting biosecurity at risk.

item.title: Brisbane Heat beat Hobart Hurricanes in stunning BBL finish
item.description: A spectacular bowling effort in the final overs and a key contribution from Marnus Labuschagne help the Brisbane Heat to an upset win over the Hobart Hurricanes to keep their BBL finals hopes alive.

item.title: Alleged firebomber charged over arson attack on shop with suspected illegal tobacco links in South West
item.description: Organised Crime detectives have charged a Perth man in relation to an alleged arson attack on a convenience store with suspected ties to illegal tobacco in the state's South West.

item.title: Large glazed windows a popular design flaw in Australian apartments, expert says
item.description: Large glazed windows are a popular design flaw in Australian apartments, according to an expert.

item.title: Drought-hit grain growers make every drop of rain count
item.description: New techniques and technology are allowing southern NSW grain growers to produce a harvest, despite significantly below-average rainfall.

item.title: Police say 11 explosive devices found on Canberra streets
item.description: Eleven explosive devices have been found next to footpaths in the city's north-west in the past two days, ACT police say.

item.title: What is the next phase of the Gaza ceasefire deal?
item.description: With little fanfare, the White House has announced "phase two" of the Gaza ceasefire has begun — at least, in terms of how it views the situation with the war-ravaged territory.

item.title: Coalition asks Albanese for the grace he was not afforded in the wake of Bondi attack
item.description: Federal Liberals are discovering the price of having been so brazen in their politicisation of the Bondi terror attack and many appear to have buyers' remorse.

item.title: Why Alice Springs has become one of Australia's most prolific literary towns
item.description: With many local authors, Alice Springs is no longer just a setting for stories by writers from elsewhere. It is becoming one of Australia's most distinctive literary centres with homegrown talent inspired by the Red Centre's landscape.

item.title: Calls for greater transparency as WA government's annual reports into youth suicide delayed
item.description: Fearing more lives will be lost, Kimberley Aboriginal leaders call on the WA government to release updates on parliamentary and coronial recommendations into youth suicide.

item.title: Moment SpaceX spacecraft with sick astronaut undocks from ISS
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: SpaceX capsule begins return to Earth from International Space Station with sick astronaut on board
item.description: The Crew Dragon capsule has undocked from the International Space Station carrying four astronauts, one of whom has a "serious medical condition", and is on its way back to Earth.

item.title: Two French men to plead guilty over alleged $10m luxury theft in Canberra
item.description: Lawyers say the value of the allegedly stolen luxury goods, including a $5 million Richard Mille watch, is disputed as the case returns to court.

item.title: Adelaide Festival Corporation apologises to Randa Abdel-Fattah over Adelaide Writers' Week call
item.description: The Adelaide Festival Corporation, which oversees Adelaide Writers' Week, has apologised to Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah and says she will be invited to speak at its next event in 2027.

item.title: River Murray, Coorong, Lake Alexandrina listed as critically endangered
item.description: Environmental protections along a huge stretch of the River Murray will be boosted, following a decision to officially list the area as "critically endangered", the federal government says.

item.title: Stolen Generation artwork discovered in trunk of regional WA museum
item.description: An artwork drawn by a child of the Stolen Generations more than 70 years ago is discovered after decades in the trunk of a regional museum.

item.title: Workers on Melbourne farm supplying Woolworths, Coles chase unpaid wages worth $260,000
item.description: According to court documents, at least 20 workers are owed money for the work they did in late 2023 on Corrigan's Farm in south-east Melbourne, which experts say is part of a bigger problem that sees tens of millions in missing cash disappear into the black economy.

item.title: Australian Open 2026: Record crowds for 'Opening Week' leave some fans frustrated
item.description: The Australian Open has smashed attendance records in what is being marketed as "Opening Week", featuring fan events and qualifying matches, but the main draw does not start until Sunday.

item.title: Families displaced by Victorian bushfires face uncertain future in tight rental market
item.description: Four weeks after unpacking their last box, a Harcourt family fled fire with only their passports and clothes — and now face a difficult search for a new rental.

item.title: Jordan Smith on winning One Point Slam
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Australian Open 2026: Who is Jordan Smith? The 1 Point Slam winner who beat Jannik Sinner
item.description: Jordan Smith comes from a tennis-mad family in Sydney and is now a millionaire thanks to a couple of days' work at the Australian Open.

item.title: From dumped shark heads to rising fury — how WA's demersal fishing ban turned ugly
item.description: Western Australia's ban on demersal fishing has left fishers frustrated. Will the government be able to soften the blow for an angry industry?

item.title: Australian Open 2026 draw puts Alex de Minaur against former Wimbledon finalist in tough first round
item.description: In the first round, the world number six will face off against Matteo Berrettini, a former Australian Open semifinalist — a place De Minaur has never progressed to himself.

item.title: How new passport rules for UK and Ireland dual citizens will work
item.description: Your guide to new UK and Ireland passport rules for dual citizens and general entry changes beginning in February.

item.title: Antonio Arena scores for Roma, raising questions over whether he will play for the Socceroos or Italy
item.description: In Italy, he has earned the nickname Il Baby Bomber because of his size, strength and impact on the game. But where do his international allegiances lie?

item.title: Neo-Nazi figure Joel Davis denied bail over alleged threat to federal MP
item.description: High-ranking neo-Nazi Joel Davis has told a Sydney court the Nationalist Socialist Network "no longer exists" as he was again denied bail for allegedly threatening a federal MP.

item.title: Tom Silvagni, son of AFL star, outlines rape conviction appeal grounds
item.description: Details of the 23-year-old's appeal bid have been released, with Silvagni arguing a judge erred in describing certain evidence as "incriminating conduct" during his rape trial late last year.

item.title: Blooming corpse flower at Adelaide Botanic Garden set to attract thousands
item.description: A corpse flower at the Adelaide Botanic Garden is generating excitement but it is actually among five of the rare plant to bloom in the city this summer.

item.title: WA health infrastructure audit delivers scathing assessment of hospital maintenance
item.description: An audit of WA's health infrastructure finds the state's aging public hospitals are too reliant on reactive maintenance, with no dedicated funding to keep them up to scratch and little data to inform future decisions.

item.title: Why Australia is investing in defence infrastructure at five military sites in the Philippines
item.description: Experts say these agreements are clear signs of how important an ally the Philippines is becoming in the Indo-Pacific region amid jitters of US security guarantees.

item.title: Record-breaking Great Ocean Road downpour sweeps cars to sea, inundates caravan parks
item.description: People in the popular holiday region have had to scramble to higher ground as a storm cell dumped more than 100 millimetres of rain, flooding campsites and washing several cars to sea.

item.title: Man charged over alleged social media death threats against PM Anthony Albanese, NSW Premier Chris Minns
item.description: WA Police charge a 19-year-old man after he allegedly uses social media to send messages, threatening to kill Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and NSW Premier Chris Minns.

item.title: Iran internet blackout enters seventh day as US President Donald Trump says violence has 'stopped'
item.description: Washington could intervene militarily in Iran, the Trump administration has suggested, but it remains unclear whether that will happen.

item.title: Greens won't support Labor's sweeping hate law reform in current form
item.description: The Greens have thrown up a roadblock for Labor by declaring it will not support the government's sweeping changes to hate and gun laws without amendments as the Coalition also backs away from the reforms.

item.title: Surgeons appear in court over alleged secret payments in Queensland hospitals
item.description: Two surgeons and the co-owner of a medical device company face Brisbane Magistrates court over their alleged involvement in public hospital fraud, allegedly involving secret payments to surgeons.

item.title: Federal officer shoots man in leg in Minneapolis after being attacked during arrest, officials say
item.description: A federal law enforcement officer has shot a man in the leg in Minneapolis after being attacked with a shovel and broom handle during an arrest, US officials say.

item.title: Dane Sweeny battles into Australian Open main draw
item.description: A delighted Dane Sweeny will play in the Australian Open main draw for the second time after winning his third and final qualifying match.

item.title: Anxious business owners fear collateral damage from WA's illegal tobacco violence
item.description: Business owners neighbouring suspected illegal tobacco stores are calling for a crackdown amid a spate of violent incidents alleged to be targeting the illicit tobacco trade.

item.title: Behind Grok's mass digital undressing lies an 'unsurprising' cohort of 'men eager to violate women'
item.description: The X AI is not creating sexually explicit images of women on its own, but the software "facilitates their abuse" acting on the requests of men "eager to violate women".

item.title: Thanasi Kokkinakis pulls out of Australian Open singles, hopeful Special Ks can still play doubles
item.description: Thanasi Kokkinakis has pulled out of the Australian Open singles before the draw could be announced after suffering a shoulder injury playing in Adelaide.

item.title: Brisbane rent prices a 'standout' among slowing capital city growth
item.description: The median asking price for a rental house in Brisbane rose by more than 3 per cent last quarter — faster than all other capitals.

item.title: Name change for viral app Are You Dead, designed for young people living alone
item.description: A viral Chinese app named Are You Dead aimed at people living alone has been rebranded to avoid controversy.

item.title: Police investigating fraud claim against director of liquidated caravan manufacturer Zone RV
item.description: The luxury caravan manufacturer will be wound up, with liquidators promising to step up their investigation into allegations against Zone RV director David Biggar.

item.title: Residents, businesses baulk at near 40pc rate hike proposal in Cessnock
item.description: Residents and small business owners in the Hunter Valley town of Cessnock say they fear the rate increase, if approved, could price people out of the area.

item.title: Laura Stein appointed as South Australia's new Chief Justice, replacing Chris Kourakis
item.description: Supreme Court Justice Laura Stein has been announced as South Australia's new Chief Justice — the first woman to be appointed to the role.

item.title: United Employment collapse leaves disability workers $6 million short in missing pay, super and entitlements
item.description: Up to 500 workers are fighting to recoup pay, super and entitlements after the collapse of a large disability support provider operating in New South Wales.

item.title: Tasmanian Liberals share, then delete image of two Labor MPs at Taste of Summer festival
item.description: The Tasmanian Liberal Party has deleted a photograph it posted on social media that showed two female Labor MPs at the Taste of Summer festival.

item.title: Cars swept into a bridge after flooding at Wye River
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Three-year-old Ineza King dies following Banya truck crash
item.description: A three-year-old girl who suffered critical head injuries in a horrific multi-vehicle crash last week in regional Queensland has died in hospital, with her family remembering her as a "beautiful spirit".

item.title: Queensland Police speak with a man in Townsville found near copper wire
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Police crack down on copper theft as main roads, telecommunication networks targeted
item.description: Officers say Operation Whiskey Biome, targeting copper theft, has led to 33 people being charged.

item.title: International Grammar School teacher Peter Adam in custody over child sexual abuse claims
item.description: A Sydney school teacher accused of plotting the sexual assault of two children he was allegedly "pimping out" to another man is refused bail.

item.title: Alice Springs residents waiting 10 years for public housing while homes sit vacant
item.description: Public housing in Alice Springs is sitting vacant and in disrepair while residents wait up to a decade to be allocated a home.

item.title: Driver's licence suspended after dog dies in alleged hit and run
item.description: A man's licence is suspended as police investigate the death of a dog in an alleged hit and run near Newcastle.

item.title: Survivors of Rottnest seaplane crash recall moments after impact, thanking those who saved them
item.description: Jeremy and Patricia Connor have publicly thanked those who rushed to help after the one-year anniversary of the crash.

item.title: Emergency workers direct traffic after crane collapse near Bangkok
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: Second fatal crane collapse tied to same company, Thai minister says
item.description: A second fatal crane collapse in two days has been linked to the same construction company, a Thai minister says.

item.title: Negin Ghadimi wanted to share her voice in protest with Iranians, she died in her father's arms
item.description: Negin Ghadimi, a 28-year-old bio-electrical engineer who "wanted to be the voice of the Iranian[s]", was shot in the stomach and killed in anti-government protests last week, her bereaved uncle says.

item.title: Bushfire relief payments cause confusion among Victorians in impact zones
item.description: Residents from Victoria's bushfire-affected areas say they are confused over disaster relief payments, with a number of people saying they have been rejected for relief despite experiencing hardship.

item.title: Thursday finance with David Chau
item.description: News from the world of finance and business. Top stories in text, video and audio. Business video news bulletin. Features and analysis.

item.title: 'Guerilla' Adelaide writers' festival could get council support
item.description: Adelaide City Council will consider supporting an alternative literary festival following the cancellation of the 2026 Adelaide Writers' Week.

item.title: Wikipedia is 25, but some old fights are still going
item.description: Wikipedia is celebrating 25 years of the online encyclopedia and the enormous impact its had, while looking forward to its future. But some controversies from the past refuse to die.

item.title: Premier Jacinta Allan vows to request formal review into Victoria's bushfire disaster
item.description: Jacinta Allan vows to request a formal review of the state's disastrous bushfire season, following days of questions over issues like Country Fire Authority resourcing and the state's disaster preparedness.

item.title: Ecologist Dr Faith Coleman steps down from government panels after allegations of political interference
item.description: South Australian ecologist Dr Faith Coleman has resigned from two state government algal bloom panels and criticised the state government's approach.

item.title: Space station astronauts splash down after first-ever medical evacuation
item.description: A capsule carrying four International Space Station crew members has splashed down in the Pacific, bringing their mission to an end more than a month early.

item.title: Newly refurbished compound at Darwin Correctional Centre to accommodate low-security female prisoners
item.description: A newly refurbished compound at the Darwin Correctional Centre will next week open to accommodate low-security female prisoners, giving them greater separation from men at the prison precinct.

item.title: NASA's Crew 11 Dragon splashdown upon returning to Earth
item.description: Follow the latest news headlines from Australia's most trusted source. Read in-depth expert analysis and watch live coverage on ABC News.

item.title: More than 4.7m social media accounts closed in two days after ban began, data reveals
item.description: More than 4.7 million Australian social media accounts have been deactivated since laws banning children aged under 16 took effect in December, according to data released by the government.

item.title: Antidepressants less effective for many living with atypical depression, new study finds
item.description: A major Australian study finds standard antidepressants are not effective for around 20 per cent of people, who may need alternative treatments.
